content.body: I was just having a bit of thought about allowing the await operator to be suffixed rather than prefixed (e.g. like `.await` in Rust).
content.formatted_body: I was just having a bit of thought about allowing the await operator to be suffixed rather than prefixed (e.g. like .await in Rust).

m.new_content.body: I was just having a bit of thought about allowing the await operator to be suffixed rather than prefixed (e.g. like `.await` in Rust)
m.new_content.formatted_body: I was just having a bit of thought about allowing the await operator to be suffixed rather than prefixed (e.g. like .await in Rust)

content.body:
This could make chaining more readable, for example
```js
// before
(await fetch()).props
await (await someAsyncMethod()).someReturnedAsyncMethod()

// after
fetch().await.props
someAsyncMethod().await.someReturnedAsyncMethod().await
```
content.formatted_body:
This could make chaining more readable, for example

// before
(await fetch()).props
await (await someAsyncMethod()).someReturnedAsyncMethod()

// after
fetch().await.props
someAsyncMethod().await.someReturnedAsyncMethod().await

content.body:
* This could make chaining more readable (reduced the need for parentheses), for example

```js
// before
(await fetch()).props
await (await someAsyncMethod()).someReturnedAsyncMethod()

// after
fetch().await.props
someAsyncMethod().await.someReturnedAsyncMethod().await
```
content.formatted_body:
*

// after
